comments.commentBody: It will be terrible for the economy and unemployed Americans when those benefits run out.  Actually, if we default on our debts and we don't have the money to pay our bills it might get terrible even sooner.  Will the government continue to send out checks?  With what?  When Republicans act like raising the debt ceiling is terrible and that the responsible thing is to refuse to do it, they forget that millions of Americans are counting on the federal treasury making payments on the bills. Those bills include benefits like the article mentioned.  If anyone doubts that we face financial disaster and a recession if we don't deal with the debt ceiling think what the country will look like when all of those who usually get their social security check, disability check, soldier's pay, etc. just don't get them.

As a community college graduate, I must say that community college for me was a wonderful investment that has paid off. I attended jr. college right out of high school, and I found that the education and the skills that I gained from hard-working, dedicated professsors were excellent.

By attending community college, I saved thousands of dollars; I transferred to a four-year university and earned a B.A. degree. Years later, I obtained a master’s degree, but I must stress that my success all started at the community college level. And I have seen countless other students—future nurses, journalists, and computer scientists, get their start at community college. It’s a shame that these colleges always seem to get less funding than big four-year colleges and universities, especially in view of the fact that some four-year schools receive very big donations from alumni.

Good insight there Jackie! Nothing will ever get done playing the centrist. You cannot defy human nature. I am convinced there is a human gene for basic personality, with polar differences of conservative and liberal, even age dependant. Both sides MUST agree to both cuts and revenue increases. It is a compromise position Obama has gambled on as a centrist. I do however, foresee disaster, as the Republicans are entrenched on the issue of taxes. We ALL know the spending must be cut, but the intransigent position of no tax increases will tax the economy even more if no agreement is reached.

It's either the vanity of Congress that wins or we all loose big time.

Ask yourself this; would you take food out of the mouths of your own family?
That's what will happen if this stubborness wins out.

This is in the BITS. So lets see the bits
Business- I personally don't think that government should not make money collecting fines and make the income to supplement our police departments. This is bad practice.To generate jobs and money one way is to make hands free phones with a place in the car to hold it. Yes this technology can be made, and implement in all the cars.
Innovation- Yes it creates innovation, and after that it can be made a law. Ask the cellphone companies to innovate, and exchange the old phones in certain period.
Technology- It should be mandatory that this technology should come into all the new cars/ trucks.
Society- I care for the people and my society, I am not against the law TO STOP texting and talking on the cellphone and driving at the same time. I was concerned when i saw people doing this. I bought an AUX wire so it helps to talk on the mic and use my car speaker. But only creating the law will not help we should provide the people an alternative.

According to the article: "con artists prey on the newly arrived and nonlawyers offer misguided advice."

No, these people are faking asylum claims. They are not victims. They were seeking advice on how to commit fraud because they knew they dod not have a chance of staying unless they concocted a lie. There is a reason that they don't tell the truth.

Let's not make excuses.
The very first thing you do when you move to another country should not be to lie. Shame on these people. Anyone caught lying should be deported.

Steve Dobrow,the deceased founder of the Comm. for Better Transit, predicted at the time of Metrocard's introduction that weekend ridership would grow faster than weekday ridership in % and in numbers; so true.
The MTA needs to repair subways on weekends and late nights; but not on
parallel lines at the same time; i.e. the A & 1. The same applies to late night Owl service.
Service frequency needs to be increased above the 10 minute standard for line specific ridership as the diagram shows; i.e. 7 on weekends & L at late nights.
Some lines should use shorturns where ridership is heavy on a modest part of the line; i.e. L at late nights in Williamsburg.
Integrating parallel bus lines better with express & local subways could offer cost savings and valuable repair time on certain lines.
Ralph Braskett

Reyes was a pretty darn good player for 4 years there before her got hurt. Reasonable to think he's somewhere between those years and this one - the main difference being his BA and triples are way up. Do you take him as a .300-ish hitter, .350 OBP who steals 30-40 annually and ignites the team?

Sure, for a rich but sane contract - say, 6 years, $110 million. A team that blows away that number is taking a big risk as would the Mets be to exceed it.

I disagree with Barry (1st poster) - I think Reyes is an elite shortstop defensively. He's much, much better than a "mid-level fielder."

Some players have continued playing simply to reach the 3,000 hit mark. Had Wage Boggs finished his season with 2,995 hits instead of 3,007, I'm sure he would have found a team on which to play a few games the following year. Players who reach 3,000 hits may feel more ready to retire having made that accomplishment. It is only those rare players who still have good years (or good contracts) ahead of them who continue playing well after that mark. If you move the milestone now it's unfair to the old players who played to the old rules. Now players will tough it out to get their 3,156th hit. Will that mean they were better than the players before them or simply that they extended their careers to meet a new criterion?

I think everyone would agree that if he kept the ball, there would be no tax consequences until he sold it. In this case, he is "selling" it for goods instead of money. The items the fan received were in exchange for the ball. The ball has a certain value, as do the items. If the items are worth more than the ball, then he would owe tax on the difference, because up to the value of the ball, it's a quid pro quo. But in this case, ironically, I would venture to guess the ball is worth more than the goods, so if I were him I would argue a loss on the transaction. The Opra example is irrelevant because the audience members gave her nothing for the cars. Same with the game show analogy. It's been a while since I went to law school, but I do remember that the facts make the law. These facts are not the same as the examples cited.
his girlfriend got him the tickets... I'm assuming as a gift... that should be taxed also!!!!
He was dumb...should have set a price of $ 1M minimum or put it up on E-bay!

All of this over a baseball?

Look how rapidly the United States is spinning out of control.

Now when the Euro dies in Europe, and Italy defaults, watch how rapidly the world spins out of control.

The IRS is the closest thing to the Nottingham Sheriff, and before long everyone will be living like a peasant, even the IRS. Total economic collapse is right around the corner.

One baseball hit into the stands defined America, how sad.

I'd be interested to know if in humans whether or not one was breastfed makes a difference. The first generations of people who were formula-fed (older baby boomers) are also one of the first generations to battle obesity on a greater scale (no pun intended) than their parents and grandparents.

Since I have definitely felt the reward centers light up when eating bites of certain foods (almost all sweet, fatty, salty or some combo thereof), I am completely unsurprised to hear there's a trigger there. Combine that with the fact that humans apparently have a limited reserve of willpower and here we have a food culture that makes it cheaper and easier to serve combinations of fat, sweet and salt food products than regular produce, and boom, our skinniest state still has an obese population of 20 percent.

What would be interesting, is to see rats raised on different diets( vegan versus carnivorous or omnivorous) diet would generate the same reaction to fatty foods.
In other words, if one were to revert or change to a low fat or vegetarian diet, and then was given a chance to indulge in foods with high content, does the reaction kick in the same way? Of is it that vast bacterial systems that live in our guts-- reacting to the introduction of fats?

OK, so now all the so called diet experts who say dieting is simply calories in versus calories out and it doesn't matter what you eat have to change their tune.  Science has finally figured out what I learned through trial and error.  If you eat high fat foods you crave them (same goes for sugar), if you stop, the cravings diminish, making it easier to stick to a new way of eating.  I used to diet by allowing myself chips and sweets if they were within my calorie plan, but after I learned this I was finally able to lose weight and keep it off long term.

@#9 It has never been proven that high intakes of saturated fat and cholesterol are detrimental to our health. The American Heart Association bases their "low-fat" prescription off of five studies:

(1) The first one was Ancel Keys study done in the 50's that generated "The Lipid Hypothesis" which argues that eating saturated fat and cholesterol give you high cholesterol, and high cholesterol gives you heart disease... totally bogus, and debunked numerous times. The debunking is best explained in Gary Taubes's "Good Calories, Bad Calories." [Basically he had data from 21 more countries but he cherry picked the seven countries that showed what he wanted to show.]

(2) The Los Angeles VA Hospital Study (1969): Researchers didn't collect data regarding smoking habits for some men, and stated later that half the participants strayed from the prescribed diet.

(3) The Oslo Diet-Heart Study (1970); basically proved nothing regarding deaths from heart disease and a low fat diet.

(4) The Finnish Mental Hospital Study (1979): almost half of the participants either left or joined half way through the 12 year study.

(5) The St. Thomas' Atherosclerosis Regression Study (1992): 74 men showed a reduction in heart disease by those who ate diets low in saturated fat... but they were also required to eat less sugar. Since the message needed to be "saturated fat bad" that little detail is often left out.

Let me sum it up: Cholesterol doesn’t lead to heart problems. Cholesterol is absolutely essential to good health. A major factor is the small dense LDL particles that cause problems.

These research findings aren't particularly "recent" and we don't need rats to show that humans can get addicted to fatty foods. Dr. Neal Barnard and other peer-reviewed scientists have long discussed the link between chocolate, cheese, meats and other products high in saturated fats with chemical-induced food addiction. The Times should post revisions and future articles that include this research. See: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5VWi6dXCT7I&feature=player_embedded.
explains why so many people who smoke dope are so skinny. they may have the munchies, but the generally do not feel like eating all that much. i better go get some marijuana right away!

Excess carbs are converted to fat.  Same difference.  Probably northern Europeans and their descendants, with a long history of fat domestic animals and heavy-carb farm crops, are more resilient to the effects of fat up to a point.  Human beings are unable to manage themselves.  We've known for many years that obesity is bad for the health, and that healthy weight is a factor of exercise and diet.  But, because we are emotion-, rather than reason-, driven, we are helpless in so many ways, and poor diet is one of them.  From what I understand, police and others, like airlines security, don't like to search fat people.  The secret is substituting healthier for unhealthier choices, as dictated by circumstances, rather than abstaining entirely.  I like to drink, but I can't or don't want to quit; however, by restricting my drinking to the hours between 6 PM - and 9 PM, I can control the situation.  Not ideal, but realistic.  I also work out 2 hours most days.  BTW I'm 58 and a little worse for the wear, so age isn't necessarily a valid excuse.

The District of Columbia has a three day waiting period and same sex marriages.  I got married there in 2003 and they also had a blood test requirement then. I don't think anyone complained about the waiting period when they allowed same sex marriages since they were just pleased to join everyone else in this anachronistic and logistical requirement.  Strangely enough I was allowed to get the license on my own before my husband flew in for our wedding, with copies of his passport.  Eventually this law may change as the blood test law did but I guess this is not on the top of the list.

We may all look back on this period, perhaps years from now, and wonder why all the well-educated and well-off politicians couldn't find a way to avoid the bleak future that awaits us beut could be avoided while there was still time.   Indeed, the problem is still fixable now.   But a few years from now the problem won't be so fixable and we will really face far harsher options than simply playing to the extremists on both sides of the aisle.  The big beneficiary of all this?   China.  The supremely pregmatic experts of power politics in Beijing couldn't be more delighted than to watch their their biggest rival dig itself into a hole so deep that it is not likely to emerge until the Chinese have long since passed us.   This will be our fate unless we choose to do something about it - now.
I think obesity may be due more to cultural influences than metabolic or brain differences.

Anyone who has struggled to lose a final 5-7 pounds for an ideal weight knows how hard it is, despite willpower.

One must press on though. We are not rats.
